State of Michigan
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RICK SNYDER NICK LYON
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 25, 2018 AMENDED
Jennifer Stevens
Samaritas - Bay
1024 Professional Drive
Flint, MI 48532
RE: License #: CB250296641
Samaritas - Bay
1024 Professional Drive
Flint, MI 48532
Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on October 15,
2018. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan (ISEP)requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not obtained and
maintained compliance for rules found in repeat non-compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

Flint, MI 48532

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated
to the staff person.
Three of fifteen new employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
One record showed one of the employee’s three references
was dated after the employee’s 7/17/18 date of hire.
A second record showed two of the employee’s three
references were dated after the employee’s 8/29/18 date of
hire.
A third record showed two of the employee’s three references
were dated after the employee’s 10/16/17 date of hire.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2016, Renewal 2015.
R400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(f) If the employee has criminal convictions, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete a written
evaluation of the convictions that addresses the nature of the
conviction, the length of time since the conviction, and the
relationship of the conviction to regulated activity.
One of fifteen new employee records reviewed showed the
employee had a misdemeanor drinking under the influence
violation prior to hire. A statement from the agency evaluating
this matter was not documented.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2015.
4

R400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(3) The agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least annually
and when needed, develop a new agreement.
One of eight open foster home records reviewed did not show
documentation the foster parent/agency agreement was
reviewed at least annually.
R400.12312 Foster parent training
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in an maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or
other institution approved by the Department.
Two of eight open foster home records reviewed showed the
foster parent’s first aid training had expired.
R400.123324 Reevaluation.
(1) An agency shall conduct an annual on-site visit and
complete a written reevaluation of a foster home.
One of eight open foster home records reviewed show the
annual reviewed was late. The annual review due by 1/21/18
was initially delayed due to an open evaluation that was
resolved 4/20/18. The foster family relocated in July and a
relocation was completed 8/14/18. The annual reevaluation was
not completed until 10/3/18.
R400.12326 Borrow home.
1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
Prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing placement
of a child in the home.
One of three borrowed home records reviewed did not show
documentation of prior approval from the certifying agency.
R400.12328 Foster home record.
(2) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(d) A placement list of all children placed in the foster home,
including all of the following about each child:
(iii)Date of, and reason for, a child’s removal from the foster
home.
5

In three of seven closed foster home records reviewed, the
placement list did not show documentation of the respective
child’s date of removal from the home and the reason.
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(a) All of the following child characteristics:
(g) Documentation of the child's placement preparation.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s preparation for placement as
defined by the rule.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016, Renewal
2015.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child's age,
appropriate to the child's capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
(e):
Two of eight open foster child records and five of eight closed
foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of the
child’s preparation for the placement change.
Repeat Violation Renewal 2017, Interim 2016, Renewal
2015.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(f) Notification to the parent, referral source, lawyer guardian ad
litem, ad courts when applicable, of the change in placement.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of notification to the referral source, court and
6

lawyer guardian ad litem related to the respective child’s
replacements.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2016, Renewal 2015.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(j) Supervisory approval before the change.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of supervisory approval before the respective
child’s change in placement.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2016, Renewal 2015.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement.
(a) A summary of service provided during care up to the time of
the change in placement and the need that remain to be met
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Three of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s needs that remain to be met and
provision for any continuing services.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical examination
shall have been completed within 12 months before placement
or a new physical examination shall be completed within 30
calendar days after placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the
child’s required physical examination due by 5/23/18, was not
obtained.
The child was moved to a residential facility on 8/3/18 and a
medical was completed 8/7/18.
7

R400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent all of the following
information before the placement or replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d)Any known history of abuse and neglect of the child.
(e)All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g)Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of
the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
clear documentation the foster parent was provided the
information outlined in (c)-(h) related to the child.
Repeat Violations Renewal 2015.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Of twenty-seven updated service plans (USP) reviewed four
were late by:
 Four days.
 Six days.
 Fifteen days.
 Fifteen days
A fifth service plan was fifty-two days late due to the referral
agency’s lateness in completing the previous service plan for
the child in MISACWIS (No corrective action plan required
related to this one).
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016, Renewal
2015.
8

R40012419 Initial Service Plan
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R400.12418(2)(a),
(h) The child management plan to be used by the foster parent.
One of one initial service plan reviewed did not show
documentation of the specific behavior management to be used
by the foster parent.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R400.12418(2)(a),
(g) A child management plan which includes any changes made
since the previous plan, and which is to be used by the foster
parents.
Four of twenty-seven updated service plans (pertaining to two
child records) reviewed did not show documentation of the
specific behavior management to be used by the foster parent.
R400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and foster parent in the foster parent’s home at least once
every month.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of a June 2018 foster home visit.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2015, cited under MSA.
R400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social services worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of four open independent living youth records reviewed did
not show documentation of an updated agreement for the youth
that were due by April and July 2018.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
9

ISEP 4.22 ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
One of eight open foster home records, two of five closed foster
home records and three of three enrolled home records
reviewed did not show compliance:
 Various records did not show consistent uploads of
various documents (applicant’s application, children’s
compliance record-3080, closing summary, letter to and
from the foster parent about closure, agency receipt
forms, 3706) and updated social work contacts.
Five of eight open foster child records reviewed did not showed
consistent compliance:
 Various records did not show all signed service plans,
signed parent/agency treatment plan agreements, FTM
DHS-1105 and or DHS-69 action summaries uploaded to
MISACWIS.
Repeat Violation Renewal 2017.
ISEP 6.33 Assessments and Service Plans Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Four of twenty-seven service plans reviewed, where a youth’s
signature was required, did not show documentation of the
youth’s signature.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016, Renewal
2015.
ISEP. 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
10

contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, and
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation that the medical passport was updated quarterly.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
clear documentation the foster parent/caregiver received the
medical passport. The foster parent’s signature was not
documented.
Repeat Violation Renewal, 2017, Interim 2016, Cited under
Policy FOM 722-11, Renewal 2015, Cite under MSA.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
Policy FOM 722- Family Meetings.
6 B
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out-lined in the following tables…
Twelve of twenty-seven service plans reviewed did not show
documentation of an FTM for the service period.
The FTMs were either not documented or occurred after the
service period.
11

Additionally, one of eight open child records reviewed showed
the child was placed with the agency, on 4/23/18 from a relative
home; and subsequently had two other placements before
returning to the relative’s home. An FTM for each move was not
documented.
Repeat Violation Renewal 2017, Interim 2016, Renewal 2015,
Cited under MSA.
Policy FOM 722- Family Meetings.
6B
Post FTM
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for the
following:
 Completing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
checking it for accuracy, identifying areas needing follow-
up, and recording the outcome data.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed, and one of
four independent living youth records reviewed did not show
consistent documentation of completion of the DHS-1105 for all
family team meetings.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016, Renewal 2015.
Policy FOM 722- Caseworker Contacts.
6 H
Unannounced Home visit.
The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the
placement every quarter. This unannounced visit must be noted
in the social work contacts of the case service plan.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
consistent documentation of an unannounced home visits for
various quarterly periods.
A fourth record also did not show compliance. In term of this
child’s case, a foster parent informed the DCWL Analyst the
agency worker does not make unannounced home visits. The
record/MISACWIS showed a 5/24/18 unannounced home visit,
related to service period 5/22/18-8/16/18, but not one for the
service period, 2/21/18-5/21/18.
Repeat Violation Renewal 2017, Interim 2016, Renewal 2015.
12

Policy FOM 722- Foster Care- Initial Service Plan.
8
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the ISP within 14 calendar days of
the Report Date.
One of one initial service plan reviewed was four days late.
Repeat Violation Renewal 2017, Renewal 2015.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care- Updated Service Plan.
9
Supervisory Approval:
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report.
Of twenty-seven updated service plans reviewed, eight
(pertaining to four of eight open child records and one of four
independent living records) were not approved/signed within 14
calendar days of the report date:
 Two were one day late.
 One was two days late.
 One was three days late.
 One was six days late
 One was seven days late.
 One was twelve days late.
 One was twenty days late.
Repeat Violations Renewal 2017, Interim 2016, Renewal
2015.
Policy FOM 722- Foster care- Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
8 C Agreement.
Signature: When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate, including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14
and older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHS office designee.
Of twenty-seven service plans reviewed seven (pertaining to
four of eight open child records) did not contain the foster
parent/caregiver’s signature.
13

Repeat Violations, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016., Renewal
2015.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care Action Summary.
09C
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a case.
The foster care action summary is generated from SWSS FAJ.
The DHS worker must complete the DHS-69, Action Summary
(RFF 69) in SWSS. Child placing agencies will continue to use
the DHS-69, Action Summary template. This form also serves
as notice to the courts of changes in placements, parent's living
situation and the FC worker/agency, as identifying information is
indicated. The FC/JJ action summary meets licensing
requirements for replacement documentation (See FOM 722-
03) and in most cases, agency transfer and case closing
summary (see below). The FC/JJ action summary must also be
used for foster care transfer to adoption.
Which Cases/ When What does this mean
All foster care cases where there is:
 A replacement.
Three of eight open child foster child records did not show
documentation of a DHS-69 for one child’s return home, a
second child’s replacement and third child’s replacements.
Policy FOM Case Closure Discharge Document.
722.15
The caseworker must provide a copy of educational documents
social security card, birth certificate, and completed medical
passport to the birth parent or guardian at the time of case
closure.
Two of eight closed foster child records reviewed, where the
child was returned to a parent or guardian did not show
documentation the items identified in the standard were
provided to the birth parent or guardian.
Policy FOM 913- Placement Resources: Child Placing Agency Reporting
4 Requirements.
Case Closure/Transfer:
Within three business days of case closure or an agency
transfer, the PAFC worker must prepare and submit a DHS-69,
Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, including a
14

narrative termination summary and the reason for termination to
all of the following individuals/entities:
 The DHS monitoring worker.
 The court.
 The child’s Lawyer Guardian Ad Litem (L-GAL).
Five of eight closed foster child records reviewed, showed the
DHS-69 was completed more than three business days of case
closure. The DHS-69 range in lateness from two days to almost
three months.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2015.
CI 16-182a Communication Issuance
Security Awareness Training for Fingerprint Base Criminal
History Requirements.
Security Awareness Training (SAT) is required for authorized
personnel who have been granted access to fingerprint-based
Criminal History Record Information (CHRI). This training
provides information on what fingerprint based CHRI is, who
has access, how to ensure this information remains secure both
physically an electronically, and how you can use this
information appropriately.
Security Awareness Training is required to be completed
no later than Tuesday February 10, 2017 for all non-
contracted and governmental CPA employees,
subcontractors, subcontractor’s employees or volunteers
who are authorized to have access to fingerprint-based
CHRI.
All non-contracted and governmental CPA employees,
subcontractors, subcontractor’s employees or volunteers who
are authorized to have access to fingerprint-based CHRI must
successfully complete SAT within six months of appointment to
a position with CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
Two of six current employees listed as having access to CHRI
did not show documentation the employee completed the
required training by the 2/10/17 due date.
Additionally, three of four employees who left the agency,
11/11/17, 6/1/18 and 9/15/18 respectively, did not show
compliance by the required due date.
15

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
Policy FOM 722-6 H page 1
All social work contacts shall be consistently linked/ documented in the service
Policy FOM 722-6H page 7, Caregiver Input
The caregiver section of the service plan shall consistent address what foster
parent reports, shares about the child’, his or her adjustment, and the foster
parent’s concerns and or comments about the child and the placement.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.1209 Orientation and Ongoing training (1)
The agency was advised documenting the employee’s required 16 hours of
orientation in LMS (Learning Management System), and ensuring the proof
document has the date, number of hours and who conducted the training, may aid it
in showing clear documentation of the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
This incident related to an allegation that the foster parent’s adult daughter, who
lived in the home had restrained the foster parent’s foster son on more than one
occasion. Additionally, that this adult daughter became aggressive with the child on
8/20/17 and had to be restrained by other adults from harming the child. The special
evaluation findings determined the adult daughter restrained the child when he
lunged at her. The foster home was not found in violation of that aspect of the
behavior management rule. The foster home was found in noncompliance of the
foster home reporting rule, for failure to report a change in the home’s composition;
because the adult daughter was visiting in the home since 7/17/17. The investigation
found that the foster parent had been “whooping” the children in the home using a
belt. The foster home was found in violation of the behavior management rule, foster
parent qualification rule and foster parent duties rule. The children were replaced
from the foster home; and revocation of the foster home’s license was
recommended.
The agency appeared to have acted appropriate in this incident and it adhered to
Departmental time frames and requirements.
16

The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2017 Renewal inspection. At
that time the agency was found in violation of a total twenty-two rule, ISEP and
policy type citations. There were no personnel/employee violations; one rule type
certification violation; and several foster care violations. The agency submitted an
acceptable corrective action plan for the Renewal inspection but was not successful
with that corrective action plan. This Interim inspection resulted in two employee
violations, five licensing violations and a slight increase in the number of foster care
violations.
It needs reporting that since the 2017 inspection, the agency experienced some
staffing turnover. Staffing changes resulted due to, staff resigning for greater
advancement, moves to DHHS (Department of Health and Human Services), one
staff’s promotion to another position, and sadly one staff died. The agency tackled
the staffing challenges by filling positions quickly, focusing on future staff retention
and trying to improve and maintain staff morale. The agency hired another foster
care supervisor, so that there is a supervisor permanently stationed at its Ann Arbor
satellite office. It is also seeking to hire a person to work directly on foster parent
recruitment and retention, to free up staff from much of this function. They are also
developing/hiring a foster care trainer supervisor. This position would focus on
trainings for new staff, staff shadowing coverage, report writing, etc., with the hope
of allowing foster supervisors to focus on their respective staff/teams and not have to
worry about all aspects of new worker tasks.
The agency has also expanded its independent living program in the Flint area. It
has acquired a rental property, which will allow six females to reside there, via
Independence Living Plus. The home is modernly furnished, very well kept and
appears to be well organized. Currently three youths reside in the dwelling.
The second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2017C0420055
pertaining to an allegation the agency did not complete a special evaluation timely.
The agency was found in violation of R400.12327(3). It submitted an acceptable
corrective action plan on 11/22/17, which indicated the matter appeared to have
been a paper issue related to the past worker and supervisor. The agency indicated
the use of internal tracking systems via “Harmony” to ensure appropriate completion
of special evaluations. The program manager, supervisor and licensing worker were
trained on the use of Harmony and tracking expectations on 11/20/17.
The agency was not successful with that corrective action plan. It received a repeat
violation of R400.1237(3) on 9/7/18 under special investigation 2018C0221035.
The third corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2018C0221035
initiated 5/9/18. The allegations related, to an issue with a placement opening;
17

special evaluation compliance/noncompliance reporting to DCWL (Department of
Child Welfare Licensing); the foster parent not being provided written notice of the
foster child’s court hearings, and foster parent rights related to court proceedings;
and a special evaluation completion timeframe. The evidence found the agency in
compliance with all rule pertaining to the allegations, exceptions R400.1327(3)
related to the special evaluation completion timeframe, no extension approval was
documented. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan that
indicated since the incident a form was created to document the request and
approval of a special evaluation report 90-day extension in writing. Additionally, that
staff had been trained on the form/process.
The agency remains in compliance with this corrective action plan
DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
Safety and Concern Alert #1:
Concern:
The foster parents have not participated in at least one Family Team Meeting for the
child placed in the home.
Resolution:
The agency reported the foster parent’s reporting was not correct. The case was
assigned to the agency on 1/23/2018 and closed on 8/30/18. The foster participated in
an FTM on 5/1/18, 7/18/18 and signed DHS-1105 FTM documents showing her
participation. MiSACWIS documentation confirmed the agency’s reporting.
Concern:
The foster parent does not receive a renewal application 60 days prior to the their
license expiring.
Resolution:
The agency reported, and case documentation showed the foster parent was mailed a
renewal application on 8/7/18. This was more than sixty days prior to the foster home’s
10/26/18 licensing expiration date.
Concern:
The foster care worker does not make unannounced home visits.
Resolution:
The agency reported the child was placed with the agency/in the foster home 1/23/18
and closed 8/30/18. The worker made an unannounced home visit on 5/24/18.
MISACWIS and service plan documentation showed that one unannounced home visit,
but not one for the service period 2/21/18- 5/21/18. A citation was issued under Policy
722-6H as documented earlier in this report.
Safety and Concern Alert #2:
18

Concern:
The foster care worker does not make unannounced home visits.
Resolution:
The agency reported and MISACWIS documentation showed the child case was
assigned to the agency in April 2018 and an unannounced home visit was completed on
4/19/18 and 7/9/18.
RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
